author: sky.cactus
content: One of the biggest problems with the EIP process is that everyone wants to make changes to Ethereum and almost no one wants to do the painful work of sifting through all of that and giving feedback on everything.  This resulted in the EIP editors narrowing scope as much as possible.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially it is down to "consensus changes only" at this point, and client APIs (other than gossip protocol) are therefore out of scope.

author: _shemnon
content: EIP editors are just format enforcers and archivists, right?  They don't have jurisdiction over technical parts? Nor are they accountable for technical feedback? So lack of quality EIP reviews isn't the editors problem.

author: _shemnon

author: sky.cactus
content: Sort of, yes.

author: sky.cactus
content: They do try to give feedback to EIP authors to make EIPs readable beyond just formatting, and to help them deal with internal conflicts, technical mistakes, etc.

author: _shemnon

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus

Your first statements in this message do not obviously lead to this conclusion.

author: _shemnon
content: It's not a problem editors alone can fix.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are suggesting that it is trivial to find "formatters and archivists who know enough about Ethereum that they can provide useful/meaningful feedback **for free**", then I will pretty strongly disagree.

author: sky.cactus
content: Editors need to understand Ethereum enough to know whether an EIP at least makes sense or not.

author: _shemnon
content: For free is the issue.  And again, the editors are not the primary source of technical review.

author: sky.cactus
content: They don't have to be experts in every system, but they need to understand enough to be able to provide useful feedback and filtering.

author: sky.cactus
content: It may surprise you the volume of *bad* EIPs that most core devs will never see because the editors "filtered" them.  Often this "filtering" is just in the form of the editor giving feedback to the author telling them 100 things they need to fix and the author then disappearing.  It is very rare (never?) that the editors will reject an EIP that the author actively iterates on and brings up to standard, but back when I was doing EIP editing maybe 90% or more of proposed drafts were dropped before making it to Review stage.

author: _shemnon

author: sky.cactus
content: I still feel that this role is important, as we can't have core devs wasting time looking at the 90% of garbage that people submit.

author: _shemnon
content: I'm not saying we don't need editors. We should have core devs reviewing good eips.

author: sky.cactus
content: The argument is that good EIP editors are a scarce resource, and it is better to spend that limited resource on consensus changes than trying to spread it out across other areas like client APIs and on-chain contract standards.

author: sky.cactus
content: We tried (for a long time) to spread it out across everything and what happened was *good* EIPs would sit waiting for editor review for over a year.

author: _shemnon
content: The problem is htat EIP editor has become a trophy job, and they are too may eip editors who insiste they have the title but don't work.  Scaring other people off from attempting to join the ivory tower.

author: sky.cactus
content: Eventually we realized the only way to fix that problem was to either increase number of editors (hard, they are a scarce resource) or decrease the scope of what editors do.

author: _shemnon
content: Remove the ones who don't work.  They are the ones who obstruct real change when it is propsed.  That's that real EIP editor issue.
